content.rendered:
Dealing with the IRS can be overwhelming, especially for taxpayers facing financial hardship. Tax advocates play a crucial role in ensuring that individuals and businesses receive fair treatment and assistance in resolving tax issues. These professionals act as intermediaries, helping taxpayers manage IRS matters while ensuring compliance with tax laws. Whether dealing with delayed refunds, collection actions, or complex disputes, tax advocates provide vital support in achieving a resolution. 

What is a Tax Advocate? 

A tax advocate is an individual or entity that helps taxpayers address IRS-related issues. They operate within different capacities, including government agencies, independent organizations, and legal clinics. Their primary objective is to assist taxpayers in overcoming challenges with the IRS by providing guidance, advocating for their taxpayer rights, and working towards equitable resolutions. 

IRS Taxpayer Advocate Explained 

The IRS Taxpayer Advocate is an essential component of the IIRS, designed to assist taxpayers experiencing significant financial or procedural difficulties. As an independent organization within the IRS, the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) helps individuals and businesses navigate complex tax issues by providing personalized assistance. TAS operates under the leadership of the National Taxpayer Advocate, who reports directly to Congress to highlight systemic problems within the IRS and suggest improvements. 

The Role of the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) 

The Taxpayer Advocate Service provides free assistance to taxpayers facing IRS-related challenges. This service acts as a safeguard against IRS procedural errors or undue hardships. TAS helps taxpayers resolve ongoing tax disputes, ensures fair treatment, and offers guidance on tax laws. Their work not only benefits individual taxpayers but also contributes to broader systemic improvements by identifying patterns of issues and recommending legislative changes. 

How Tax Advocates Assist Taxpayers 

Tax advocates offer a range of services designed to help individuals and businesses navigate IRS procedures. Their assistance often includes helping with delayed refunds, preventing collection actions, and securing fair installment agreements. 

Free Taxpayer Assistance Services 

One of the most significant benefits of tax advocates is the free assistance they provide. The IRS, in partnership with various legal clinics and nonprofit organizations, offers taxpayer assistance programs to help low-income individuals and small businesses. These services include Low Income Taxpayer Clinics (LITCs), which provide representation for eligible taxpayers facing IRS disputes, and Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA) programs, which offer free tax preparation help. 

Understanding IRS Publication 1546 and Form 911 

IRS Publication 1546 serves as a guide to the Taxpayer Advocate Service, outlining the rights of taxpayers and explaining the assistance available to those facing IRS difficulties. Form 911 is a critical document that taxpayers can use to request assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate Service. This form is essential for individuals experiencing significant hardship due to IRS actions, such as a delay in refund processing or an unjustified collection effort. By submitting Form 911, taxpayers can formally request intervention from TAS, ensuring a fair and expedited resolution. 

Problem Solving Days: Direct Interaction Opportunities 

Problem Solving Days provide taxpayers with a unique opportunity to interact directly with the IRS to resolve their tax issues. These events, hosted by the Taxpayer Advocate Service, allow individuals to meet with IRS representatives and discuss their cases in person. Problem Solving Days are particularly beneficial for taxpayers who have been unable to resolve their issues through traditional IRS channels, as they facilitate direct communication and expedite resolutions. 

Addressing Common Taxpayer Issues 

Tax advocates help taxpayers tackle a wide range of IRS-related issues, ensuring that they receive the assistance needed to resolve their problems efficiently. 

Resolving Delayed Tax Refunds and Responses 

One of the most common complaints among taxpayers is the delay in receiving refunds. The Taxpayer Advocate Service assists individuals facing prolonged refund processing times, particularly when delays cause financial hardship. TAS intervenes by identifying the cause of the delay and working with the IRS to expedite the refund.  

Additionally, tax advocates help taxpayers who struggle to receive responses from the IRS regarding disputes, appeals, or other concerns. When standard IRS communication channels fail, TAS can step in to ensure taxpayers receive the necessary assistance. 

Handling Immediate Financial or Procedural Threats 

Taxpayers facing immediate financial hardship due to IRS actions can seek assistance from TAS. Common situations where TAS intervenes include: 

Stopping IRS Collection Actions: 

If a taxpayer is subject to a levy, lien, or wage garnishment, TAS can work to halt these actions if they cause undue financial strain.  Tax advocates intervene by: 

  • Requesting a Hold on Collection Actions: Tax advocates can request the IRS to stop or temporarily hold collection actions, such as garnishing wages or seizing assets, particularly if the taxpayer is facing undue hardship. 
  • Negotiating for a Release: They can work with the IRS to have levies or liens released, allowing the taxpayer to access essential funds and avoid further financial damage. 
  • Providing Financial Hardship Documentation: They help compile necessary documents that prove financial hardship, convincing the IRS to pause collection actions while the taxpayer works on a resolution. 

Advocating for Installment Agreements: 

TAS helps taxpayers negotiate installment agreements with the IRS to make manageable monthly payments on their tax debt. In some cases, they can advocate for the removal or reduction of penalties, making the debt more affordable. 

Handling IRS Audits or Disputes: 

Taxpayers under audit or facing disputes can receive guidance from TAS to ensure their rights are protected. Tax advocates: 

  • Serve as Intermediaries: They represent the taxpayer and handle all communications with the IRS, reducing stress and confusion. 
  • Protect Taxpayer Rights: They ensure the taxpayer’s rights are upheld throughout the audit process, preventing unfair treatment or procedural errors. 
  • Assist with Dispute Resolution: If there is a disagreement about tax liabilities, tax advocates can help negotiate settlements or suggest alternatives like an Offer in Compromise. 

Preventing Immediate Financial Hardship: 

If IRS actions result in severe financial distress, TAS can intervene to:  

  • Temporarily Delaying Collection Actions: If a taxpayer is unable to pay their tax debt because of job loss or medical emergencies, a tax advocate can request the IRS delay collection actions until the taxpayer’s situation stabilizes. 
  • Requesting a “Currently Not Collectible” Status: If the taxpayer can’t pay due to severe financial hardship, a tax advocate can request that the IRS designate the account as “Currently Not Collectible,” temporarily halting all collection efforts. 

Assisting with Taxpayer Rights: 

TAS educates taxpayers about their rights and ensures that the IRS follows proper procedures in all interactions.  

Taxpayer Assistance Orders: A Powerful Tool 

Taxpayer Assistance Orders (TAOs) are a powerful mechanism used by the Taxpayer Advocate Service to stop IRS actions that cause significant hardship. These orders compel the IRS to suspend certain activities or reconsider decisions in cases where taxpayers face severe financial or procedural difficulties. 

Common examples of Taxpayer Assistance Orders include: 

  1. Release of Levy or Lien: If an IRS levy or lien causes undue hardship, TAS can issue a TAO to release the action. 
  1. Stopping Wage Garnishments: Taxpayers experiencing financial distress due to wage garnishments can seek relief through TAS intervention. 
  1. Preventing Bank Account Seizure: TAS can halt IRS actions that threaten a taxpayer’s financial security, such as bank levies. 
  1. Discharging Certain Tax Liabilities: In cases where a taxpayer faces extreme hardship, TAS may work to modify or discharge certain liabilities. 
  1. Extension of Time: If a taxpayer requires additional time to meet IRS obligations, TAS can request extensions to prevent unnecessary penalties or interest accruals. 

The Impact and Goals of Taxpayer Advocates 

Beyond assisting individual taxpayers, tax advocates contribute to systemic improvements within the IRS by identifying patterns of issues and recommending changes to enhance tax administration. 

Advocacy for Individuals and Businesses 

Taxpayer advocates serve both individuals and businesses, ensuring that tax laws are applied fairly and that taxpayers receive appropriate support in navigating IRS challenges. Small business owners, in particular, benefit from tax advocate assistance when dealing with audits, disputes, and compliance issues. 

Legislative Recommendations and Systemic Changes 

The Taxpayer Advocate Service plays a significant role in recommending legislative changes to improve the tax system. Through annual reports to Congress, the National Taxpayer Advocate highlights inefficiencies, proposes solutions, and advocates for reforms that benefit taxpayers. This ongoing advocacy helps shape tax policies, ensuring a fairer and more transparent system for all. 

Tax Help for Those Who Owe 

Tax advocates are essential in helping taxpayers navigate complex IRS challenges, ensuring fair treatment and efficient resolution of tax issues. From providing direct assistance to influencing systemic changes, tax advocates play a crucial role in improving the overall tax system. By leveraging their expertise and support, taxpayers can confidently address their IRS concerns and achieve better financial outcomes. If the Taxpayer Advocate Service cannot assist, taxpayers can seek professional help from firms like Optima Tax Relief to explore additional solutions. Optima Tax Relief is the nation’s leading tax resolution firm with over $3 billion in resolved tax liabilities.
